COMING EVENTS.

Roger had turned over many plans in his (Roger) mind, by which he (Roger) thought that he (Roger) could obtain sufficient money for the purpose he (Roger) desired to accomplish. His (Roger) careful grandfather, who had been a merchant in the city, had so tied up the few thousands he (Roger) had left to his (Roger) daughter, that although, in case of her (daughter) death before her (daughter) husband's, the latter might enjoy the life-interest thereof, yet, in case of both their deaths, their second son did not succeed to the property until he (son) was five-and-twenty; and if he (son) died before that age, the money that would then have been his (son) went to one of his (son) cousins on the maternal side. In short, the old merchant had taken as many precautions about his (merchant) legacy as if it had been for tens, instead of units of thousands. Of course Roger might have slipped through all these meshes by insuring his (Roger) life until the specified age; and, probably, if he (Roger) had consulted any lawyer, this course would have been suggested to him (Roger). But he (Roger) disliked taking any one into his (Roger) confidence on the subject of his (Roger) father's want of ready money. CHAPTER XXXIII.

BRIGHTENING PROSPECTS.

-LSB-Illustration -LRB-untitled-RRB--RSB-

It was a day or two afterwards, that Mr. Gibson made time to ride round by Hamley, desirous to learn more exact particulars of this scheme for Roger than he (Roger) could obtain from any extraneous source, and rather puzzled to know whether he (Roger) should interfere in the project or not. The state of the case was this:--Osborne's symptoms were, in Mr. Gibson's opinion, signs of his (Gibson) having a fatal disease. Dr. Nicholls had differed from him (Gibson) on this head, and Mr. Gibson knew that the old physician had had long experience, and was considered very skilful in the profession. Still he (Gibson) believed that he (Gibson) himself was right, and, if so, the complaint was one which might continue for years in the same state as at present, or might end the young man's life in an hour--a minute. Supposing that Mr. Gibson was right, would it be well for Roger to be away where no sudden calls for his (Gibson) presence could reach him (Gibson)--away for two years? Yet if the affair was concluded, the interference of a medical man might accelerate the very evil to be feared; and after all, Dr. Nicholls might be right, and the symptoms might proceed from some other cause. Might? Yes. Probably did? No. Mr. Gibson could not bring himself to say

``yes'' (Mr. Gibson/MR. GIBSON)
to this latter form of sentence. So he (Gibson) rode on, meditating; his (Gibson) reins slack, his (Gibson) head a little bent. It was one of those still and lovely autumn days when the red and yellow leaves are hanging-pegs to dewy, brilliant gossamer-webs; when the hedges are full of trailing brambles, loaded with ripe blackberries; when the air is full of the farewell whistles and pipes of birds, clear and short--not the long full-throated warbles of spring; when the whirr of the partridge's wings is heard in the stubble-fields, as the sharp hoof-blows fall on the paved lanes; when here and there a leaf floats and flutters down to the ground, although there is not a single breath of wind. The country surgeon felt the beauty of the seasons perhaps more than most men. He (surgeon) saw more of it by day, by night, in storm and sunshine, or in the still, soft, cloudy weather. He (surgeon) never spoke about what he (surgeon) felt on the subject; indeed, he (surgeon) did not put his (surgeon) feelings into words, even to himself. He (Squire) was to go first to Paris, to have interviews with some of the scientific men there. The last day he (Roger) rode into Hollingford earlier than he (Roger) needed to have done to catch the London coach, in order to bid the Gibsons good-by. He (Roger) had been too actively busy for some time to have leisure to bestow much thought on Cynthia; but there was no need for fresh meditation on that subject. CHAPTER XXXV.

THE MOTHER``S MANOEUVRE.

Mr. Gibson was not at home at dinner--detained by some patient, most probably. This was not an unusual occurrence; but it _was_ rather an unusual occurrence for Mrs. Gibson to go down into the dining-room, and sit with him (Gibson) as he (Gibson) ate his (Gibson) deferred meal when he (Gibson) came in an hour or two later. DOMESTIC DIPLOMACY.

CHAPTER XXXVII.

A FLUKE, AND WHAT CAME OF IT.

-LSB-Illustration -LRB-untitled-RRB--RSB-

CHAPTER XLII.

THE STORM BURSTS.

The autumn drifted away through all its seasons. The golden corn-harvest, the walks through the stubble-fields, and rambles into hazel-copses in search of nuts; the stripping of the apple-orchards of their ruddy fruit, amid the joyous cries and shouts of watching children; and the gorgeous tulip-like colouring of the later time had now come on with the shortening days. There was comparative silence in the land, excepting for the distant shots, and the whirr of the partridges as they rose up from the field.

CHAPTER XLIV.

MOLLY GIBSON TO THE RESCUE.

It seemed curious enough, after the storms of the night, to meet in smooth tranquillity at breakfast. Cynthia was pale; but she (Cynthia) talked as quietly as usual about all manner of indifferent things, while Molly sate silent, watching and wondering, and becoming convinced that Cynthia must have gone through a long experience of concealing her (Cynthia) real thoughts and secret troubles before she (Cynthia) could have been able to put on such a semblance of composure. Among the letters that came in that morning was one from the London Kirkpatricks; but not from Helen, Cynthia's own particular correspondent. Her (Cynthia) sister wrote to apologize for Helen, who was not well, she (Cynthia) said: had had the influenza, which had left her (Cynthia) very weak and poorly.

``The country at this time of the year is better than London, except when the place is surrounded by trees. Now our house is well drained, high up, gravel-soil, and I'll undertake to doctor her (you) for nothing.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER XLV.

CONFIDENCES.

All the rest of that day Molly was depressed and not well. Having anything to conceal was so unusual--almost so unprecedented a circumstance with her (Molly) that it preyed upon her (Molly) in every way.

(she)

Scandal sleeps in the summer, comparatively speaking. Its nature is the reverse of that of the dormouse. Warm ambient air, loiterings abroad, gardenings, flowers to talk about, and preserves to make, soothed the wicked imp to slumber in the parish of Hollingford in summer-time. But when evenings grew short, and people gathered round the fires, and put their feet in a circle--not on the fenders, that was not allowed--then was the time for confidential conversation! CHAPTER XLVII.

SCANDAL AND ITS VICTIMS.

When Mr. Gibson returned to Hollingford, he (Gibson) found an accumulation of business waiting for him (Gibson), and he (Gibson) was much inclined to complain of the consequences of the two days' comparative holiday, which had resulted in over-work for the week to come. He (Gibson) had hardly time to speak to his (Gibson) family, he (Gibson) had so immediately to rush off to pressing cases of illness. ``I'll go and see him (Hamley); don't tell your mother where I'm gone: you've not mentioned this to her (mother), I hope?'' (he)

``No,'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)

``nervous,'' (Osborne/Mrs. Hamley/Hamley)

Cynthia herself struggled with the feeling, and tried to fight against it by calling herself
``ungrateful;'' (Cynthia/Cynthia Kirkpatrick/CYNTHIA)

The operation on Lady Cumnor had been successfully performed, and in a few days they hoped to bring her (Cumnor) down to the Towers to recruit her (Cumnor) strength in the fresh country air. The case was one which interested Mr. Gibson extremely, and in which his (Gibson) opinion had been proved to be right, in opposition to that of one or two great names in London. All these days the buzzing gossip about Molly's meetings with Mr. Preston, her (Molly) clandestine correspondence, the secret interviews in lonely places, had been gathering strength, and assuming the positive form of scandal. The simple innocent girl, who walked through the quiet streets without a thought of being the object of mysterious implications, became for a time the unconscious black sheep of the town. Servants heard part of what was said in their mistresses' drawing-rooms, and exaggerated the sayings amongst themselves with the coarse strengthening of expression common with uneducated people. The answer was silly enough, logically; but forcible in fact. Cynthia was Cynthia, and not Venus herself could have been her (Cynthia) substitute. In this one thing Mr. Preston was more really true than many worthy men; who, seeking to be married, turn with careless facility from the unattainable to the attainable, and keep their feelings and fancy tolerably loose till they find a woman who consents to be their wife. There came a time--not very distant from the evening at Mrs. Dawes'--when Molly felt that people looked askance at her (Molly). AN INNOCENT CULPRIT.

MOLLY GIBSON FINDS A CHAMPION.

``the family'' (time wanderers)

CHAPTER L.

CYNTHIA AT BAY.

Mrs. Gibson was slow in recovering her (Gibson) strength after the influenza, and before she (Gibson) was well enough to accept Lady Harriet's invitation to the Towers, Cynthia came home from London. CHAPTER LVII.

BRIDAL VISITS AND ADIEUX.

The whole town of Hollingford came to congratulate and inquire into particulars. Some indeed--Mrs. Goodenough at the head of this class of malcontents--thought that they were defrauded of their right to a fine show by Cynthia's being married in London. CHAPTER LVIII.

REVIVING HOPES AND BRIGHTENING PROSPECTS.

``If you can without fatigue, dear, do come down to dinner to-day; you'll then see the people one by one as they appear, instead of having to encounter a crowd of strangers. Hollingford will be here too. I hope you'll find it pleasant.'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)

So Molly made her (Molly) appearance at dinner that day; and got to know, by sight at least, some of the most distinguished of the visitors at the Towers. The next day was Thursday, Cynthia's wedding-day; bright and fine in the country, whatever it might be in London. He (Roger) was annoyed when Sir Charles, whose especial charge she (girl) still was, came up to take her (girl) in to dinner. Lord Hollingford carried off Roger to the cluster of middle-aged men; he (Roger) was wanted to give his (Roger) opinion upon some scientific subject. ``Really, Charles, considering that she (girl) is in your charge, I think you might have saved her (girl) from the chatter and patter of Mr. Watson; I can only stand it when I am in the strongest health.'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)

CHAPTER LIX.

MOLLY GIBSON AT HAMLEY HALL.

The conversation ended there for the time. Wedding-cake and wine were brought in, and it was Molly's duty to serve them out. But those last words of Mrs. Goodenough's tingled in her (Goodenough) ears, and she (Goodenough) tried to interpret them to her (Goodenough) own satisfaction in any way but the obvious one. And that, too, was destined to be confirmed; for directly after Mrs. Goodenough took her (Goodenough) leave, Mrs. Gibson desired Molly to carry away the tray to a table close to an open corner window, where the things might be placed in readiness for any future callers; and underneath this open window went the path from the house-door to the road. ``That Mrs. Gibson is a deep `un. There's Mr. Roger Hamley as like as not to have the Hall estate, and she (Gibson) sends Molly a-visiting--'' (grand-daughter)

Molly could have burst out crying, with a full sudden conviction of what Mrs. Goodenough had been alluding to: her (Goodenough) sense of the impropriety of Molly's going to visit at the Hall when Roger was at home. To be sure, Mrs. Goodenough was a commonplace, unrefined woman. Mrs. Gibson did not seem to have even noticed the allusion. Mr. Gibson took it all as a matter of course that Molly should go to the Hall as simply now, as she (Molly) had done before. Roger had spoken of it in so straightforward a manner as showed he (Roger) had no conception of its being an impropriety,--this visit,--this visit until now so happy a subject of anticipation. Molly felt as if she (Molly) could never speak to any one of the idea to which Mrs. Goodenough's words had given rise; as if she (Goodenough) could never be the first to suggest the notion of impropriety, which presupposed what she (Goodenough) blushed to think of. Then she (Goodenough) tried to comfort herself by reasoning. If it had been wrong, forward, or indelicate, really improper in the slightest degree, who would have been so ready as her (Goodenough) father to put his (father) veto upon it? But reasoning was of no use after Mrs. Goodenough's words had put fancies into Molly's head. The more she (Molly) bade these fancies begone the more they answered her (Molly) -LRB-as Daniel O``Rourke did the man in the moon, when he (Rourke) bade Dan get off his (Dan) seat on the sickle, and go into empty space-RRB-:--
``The more ye ask us the more we won't stir.'' (Daniel)
One may smile at a young girl's miseries of this kind; but they are very real and stinging miseries to her (Molly). All that Molly could do was to resolve on a single eye to the dear old Squire, and his (Squire) mental and bodily comforts; to try and heal up any breaches which might have occurred between him (Squire) and Aimée; and to ignore Roger as much as possible. It would be very hard to avoid him (Roger) as much as was consistent with common politeness; but it would be right to do it; and when she (Molly) was with him (Roger) she (Molly) must be as natural as possible, or he (Roger) might observe some difference; but what was natural? CHAPTER LX.

ROGER HAMLEY``S CONFESSION.

Roger had a great deal to think of as he (Roger) turned away from looking after the carriage as long as it could be seen. Yet she (mother)'s a coward, and doesn't speak out her (mother) mind. Now by being in lodgings, and having her (mother) own servants--nice pretty rooms they are, too; we went to see them, and Mrs. Jennings promises to attend well to Mrs. Osborne Hamley, and is very much honoured, and all that sort of thing--not ten minutes' walk from the Hall, too, so that she (Hamley) and the little chap may easily go backwards and forwards as often as they like, and yet she (Hamley) may keep the control over the child's discipline and diet. In short, I think I've done a good day's work,'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)
he (Gibson) continued, stretching himself a little; and then with a shake rousing himself, and making ready to go out again, to see a patient who had sent for him (patient) in his (patient) absence.

``A good day's work!'' (he)
he (patient) repeated to himself as he (patient) ran downstairs.
``I don't know when I have been so happy!'' (he)
For he (patient) had not told Molly all that had passed between him (patient) and Roger. Roger had begun a fresh subject of conversation just as Mr. Gibson was hastening away from the Hall, after completing the new arrangement for Aimée and her (Molly) child.

``You know that I set off next Tuesday, Mr. Gibson, don't you?'' (Roger/Roger Hamley/Mr. Roger Hamley)
said Roger, a little abruptly.

``To be sure. I hope you'll be as successful in all your scientific objects as you were the last time, and have no sorrows awaiting you when you come back.'' (unknown)

``Thank you. Yes. I hope so. You don't think there's any danger of infection now, do you?'' (unknown)

``No! If the disease were to spread through the household, I think we should have had some signs of it before now. One is never sure, remember, with scarlet fever.'' (Roger/Roger Hamley/Mr. Roger Hamley)

``Should you be afraid,'' (he)
he (Roger) said at length,

``Then I shall not see Molly again!'' (Roger/Roger Hamley/Mr. Roger Hamley)
said Roger, in a tone and with a look of great disappointment.

Mr. Gibson turned his (Gibson) keen, observant eyes upon the young man, and looked at him (Gibson) in as penetrating a manner as if he (Gibson) had been beginning with an unknown illness. Then the doctor and the father compressed his (doctor) lips and gave vent to a long intelligent whistle.

``Whew!'' (he)
said he (doctor).

he (Roger) pleaded.

said Mr. Gibson, more affected than he (Gibson) liked to show, and laying his (Gibson) hand on Roger's shoulder. Then he (Roger) pulled himself up, and said gravely enough,--

``Not much. I did love Cynthia very much. Mr. Gibson gave Roger's message to his (Gibson) wife and to Molly that evening at dinner. It was but what the latter had expected, after all her (Molly) father had said of the very great danger of infection; but now that her (Molly) expectation came in the shape of a final decision, it took away her (Molly) appetite. ``Lover _versus_ father!'' (he)
thought he (father), half sadly.
``Lover wins.'' (he)
And he (father), too, became indifferent to all that remained of his (father) dinner. Mrs. Gibson pattered on; and nobody listened.

The day of Roger's departure came. Molly tried hard to forget it in working away at a cushion she (Molly) was preparing as a present to Cynthia; people did worsted-work in those days. One, two, three. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven; all wrong: she (Cynthia) was thinking of something else, and had to unpick it. It was a rainy day, too; and Mrs. Gibson, who had planned to go out and pay some calls, had to stay indoors. This made her (Gibson) restless and fidgety. She (Gibson) kept going backwards and forwards to different windows in the drawing-room to look at the weather, as if she (Gibson) imagined that while it rained at one window, it might be fine weather at another.

``Molly--come here! who is that man wrapped up in a cloak,--there,--near the Park wall, under the beech-tree--he (man) has been there this half-hour and more, never stirring, and looking at this house all the time! I think it's very suspicious.'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)

Molly looked, and in an instant recognized Roger under all his (Roger) wraps. Her (Molly) first instinct was to draw back. The next to come forwards, and say--

``Why, mamma, it's Roger Hamley! Look now--he (Hamley)'s kissing his (Hamley) hand; he (Hamley)'s wishing us good-by in the only way he (Hamley) can!'' (she)
And she (Molly) responded to his (Roger) sign; but she (Molly) was not sure if he (Roger) perceived her (Molly) modest quiet movement, for Mrs. Gibson became immediately so demonstrative that Molly fancied that her (Molly) eager foolish pantomimic motions must absorb all his (Roger) attention.

``I call this so attentive of him (Hamley),'' (Mrs. Gibson/MRS. GIBSON)
said Mrs. Gibson, in the midst of a volley of kisses of her (Gibson) hand.
``Really, it is quite romantic. It reminds me of former days--but he (Hamley) will be too late! I must send him (Hamley) away; it is half-past twelve!'' (she)
And she (Gibson) took out her (Gibson) watch and held it up, tapping it with her (Gibson) forefinger, and occupying the very centre of the window. Molly could only peep here and there, dodging now up, now down, now on this side, now on that, of the perpetually-moving arms. She (Molly) fancied she (Molly) saw something of a corresponding movement on Roger's part. At length he (Roger) went away slowly, slowly, and often looking back, in spite of the tapped watch. Mrs. Gibson at last retreated, and Molly quietly moved into her (Molly) place to see his (Roger) figure once more before the turn of the road hid it from her (Molly) view. He (Roger), too, knew where the last glimpse of Mr. Gibson's house was to be obtained, and once more he (Gibson) turned, and his (Gibson) white handkerchief floated in the air. Molly waved hers high up, with eager longing that it should be seen. And then, he (Gibson) was gone! and Molly returned to her (Molly) worsted-work, happy, glowing, sad, content, and thinking to herself how sweet is--friendship!

When she (Molly) came to a sense of the present, Mrs. Gibson was saying,--

``Upon my word, though Roger Hamley has never been a great favourite of mine, this little attention of his (Hamley) has reminded me very forcibly of a very charming young man--a _soupirant_, as the French would call him (Hamley)--Lieutenant Harper--you must have heard me speak of him (Harper), Molly?'' (Mrs. Gibson/MRS. GIBSON)

``I think I have!'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)
said Molly, absently.

``Well, you remember how devoted he (Harper) was to me when I was at Mrs. Duncombe's, my first situation, and I only seventeen. And when the recruiting party was ordered to another town, poor Mr. Harper came and stood opposite the schoolroom window for nearly an hour, and I know it was his (Harper) doing that the band played ``The girl I left behind me,

'' when they marched out the next day. Poor Mr. Harper! It was before I knew dear Mr. Kirkpatrick! Dear me. How often my poor heart has had to bleed in this life of mine! not but what dear papa is a very worthy man, and makes me very happy. He (man) would spoil me, indeed, if I would let him (man). Still he (man) is not as rich as Mr. Henderson.'' (me)

That last sentence contained the germ of Mrs. Gibson's present grievance. Having married Cynthia, as her (Cynthia) mother put it--taking credit to herself as if she (Cynthia) had had the principal part in the achievement--she (Cynthia) now became a little envious of her (Cynthia) daughter's good fortune in being the wife of a young, handsome, rich, and moderately fashionable man, who lived in London. She (Cynthia) naïvely expressed her (Cynthia) feelings on this subject to her (Cynthia) husband one day when she (Cynthia) was really not feeling quite well, and when consequently her (Cynthia) annoyances were much more present to her (Cynthia) mind than her (Cynthia) sources of happiness.

``It is such a pity!'' (she)
said she (Cynthia),
``that I was born when I was. I should so have liked to belong to this generation.'' (she)

``That's sometimes my own feeling,'' (he)
said he (husband).
``So many new views seem to be opened in science, that I should like, if it were possible, to live till their reality was ascertained, and one saw what they led to. But I don't suppose that's your reason, my dear, for wishing to be twenty or thirty years younger.'' (unknown)

``No, indeed. And I did not put it in that hard unpleasant way; I only said I should like to belong to this generation. To tell the truth, I was thinking of Cynthia. Without vanity, I believe I was as pretty as she (Cynthia) is--when I was a girl, I mean; I had not her (Cynthia) dark eyelashes, but then my nose was straighter. And now look at the difference! I have to live in a little country town with three servants, and no carriage; and she (Cynthia) with her (Cynthia) inferior good looks will live in Sussex Place, and keep a man and a brougham, and I don't know what. ``Oh, ho! so that's your reason, is it, my dear? If you had been young now you might have married somebody as well off as Walter?'' (unknown)

``Yes!'' (she)
said she (Cynthia).
``I think that was my idea. Of course I should have liked him (Walter) to be you. I always think if you had gone to the bar you might have succeeded better, and lived in London, too. I don't think Cynthia cares much where she (Cynthia) lives, yet you see it has come to her (Cynthia).'' (unknown)

``What has--London?'' (unknown)

``Oh, you dear, facetious man. Now that's just the thing to have captivated a jury. I don't believe Walter will ever be so clever as you are. Yet he (Walter) can take Cynthia to Paris, and abroad, and everywhere. I only hope all this indulgence won't develope the faults in Cynthia's character. It's a week since we heard from her (Cynthia), and I did write so particularly to ask her (Cynthia) for the autumn fashions before I bought my new bonnet. But riches are a great snare.'' (unknown)

``Be thankful you are spared temptation, my dear.'' (unknown)

``No, I'm not. Everybody likes to be tempted. And, after all, it's very easy to resist temptation, if one wishes.'' (unknown)

``I don't find it so easy,'' (husband)
said her (Cynthia) husband.

``Here's medicine for you, mamma,'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)
said Molly, entering with a letter held up in her (Molly) hand.
``A letter from Cynthia.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you dear little messenger of good news! There was one of the heathen deities in Mangnall's Questions whose office it was to bring news. The letter is dated from Calais. They're coming home! She (Cynthia)'s bought me a shawl and a bonnet! The dear creature! Always thinking of others before herself: good fortune cannot spoil her (Cynthia). They've a fortnight left of their holiday! Their house is not quite ready; they're coming here. Oh, now, Mr. Gibson, we must have the new dinner-service at Watts's I've set my heart on so long!

``Home' Cynthia calls this house. I'm sure it has been a home to her (Cynthia), poor darling! I doubt if there is another man in the world who would have treated his (man) step-daughter like dear papa! And, Molly, you must have a new gown.'' (unknown)

I must have a new gown too. It won't do to look as if we had nothing but the dresses which we wore at the wedding!'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)

But Molly stood out against the new gown for herself, and urged that if Cynthia and Walter were to come to visit them often, they had better see them as they really were, in dress, habits, and appointments. When Mr. Gibson had left the room, Mrs. Gibson softly reproached Molly for her (Gibson) obstinacy.

``You might have allowed me to beg for a new gown for you, Molly, when you knew how much I had admired that figured silk at Brown's the other day. And now, of course, I can't be so selfish as to get it for myself, and you to have nothing. You should learn to understand the wishes of other people. Still, on the whole, you are a dear, sweet girl, and I only wish--well, I know what I wish; only dear papa does not like it to be talked about. And now cover me up close, and let me go to sleep, and dream about my dear Cynthia and my new shawl!'' (unknown)

* * * * * *

CONCLUDING REMARKS:

-LSB-By the Editor of _The Cornhill Magazine_.-RSB-

Here the story is broken off, and it can never be finished. What promised to be the crowning work of a life is a memorial of death. A few days longer, and it would have been a triumphal column, crowned with a capital of festal leaves and flowers: now it is another sort of column--one of those sad white pillars which stand broken in the churchyard.

But if the work is not quite complete, little remains to be added to it, and that little has been distinctly reflected into our minds. We know that Roger Hamley will marry Molly, and that is what we are most concerned about. Indeed, there was little else to tell. Had the writer lived, she (Molly) would have sent her (Molly) hero back to Africa forthwith; and those scientific parts of Africa are a long way from Hamley; and there is not much to choose between a long distance and a long time. How many hours are there in twenty-four when you are all alone in a desert place, a thousand miles from the happiness which might be yours to take--if you were there to take it? How many, when from the sources of the Topinambo your heart flies back ten times a day, like a carrier-pigeon, to the one only source of future good for you, and ten times a day returns with its message undelivered? Many more than are counted on the calendar. So Roger found. The days were weeks that separated him (Roger) from the time when Molly gave him (Roger) a certain little flower, and months from the time which divorced him (Roger) from Cynthia, whom he (Roger) had begun to doubt before he (Roger) knew for certain that she (Cynthia) was never much worth hoping for. And if such were his (Roger) days, what was the slow procession of actual weeks and months in those remote and solitary places? They were like years of a stay-at-home life, with liberty and leisure to see that nobody was courting Molly meanwhile. The effect of this was, that long before the term of his (Roger) engagement was ended all that Cynthia had been to him (Roger) was departed from Roger's mind, and all that Molly was and might be to him (Roger) filled it full.

He (Roger) returned; but when he (Roger) saw Molly again he (Roger) remembered that to her (Molly) the time of his (Roger) absence might not have seemed so long, and was oppressed with the old dread that she (Molly) would think him (Roger) fickle. Therefore this young gentleman, so self-reliant and so lucid in scientific matters, found it difficult after all to tell Molly how much he (gentleman) hoped she (Molly) loved him (gentleman); and might have blundered if he (gentleman) had not thought of beginning by showing her (Molly) the flower that was plucked from the nosegay. How charmingly that scene would have been drawn, had Mrs. Gaskell lived to depict it, we can only imagine: that it _would_ have been charming--especially in what Molly did, and looked, and said--we know.

Roger and Molly are married; and if one of them is happier than the other, it is Molly. Her (Molly) husband has no need to draw upon the little fortune which is to go to poor Osborne's boy, for he (boy) becomes professor at some great scientific institution, and wins his (boy) way in the world handsomely. The squire is almost as happy in this marriage as his (boy) son. If any one suffers for it, it is Mr. Gibson. But he (Gibson) takes a partner, so as to get a chance of running up to London to stay with Molly for a few days now and then, and

``to get a little rest from Mrs. Gibson.'' (Molly/Gibson/Molly Gibson)
Of what was to happen to Cynthia after her (Cynthia) marriage the author was not heard to say much; and, indeed, it does not seem that anything needs to be added. One little anecdote, however, was told of her (Cynthia) by Mrs. Gaskell, which is very characteristic. One day, when Cynthia and her (Cynthia) husband were on a visit to Hollingford, Mr. Henderson learned for the first time, through an innocent casual remark of Mr. Gibson's, that the famous traveller, Roger Hamley, was known to the family. Cynthia had never happened to mention it. How well that little incident, too, would have been described!

But it is useless to speculate upon what would have been done by the delicate strong hand which can create no more Molly Gibsons--no more Roger Hamleys. We have repeated, in this brief note, all that is known of her (Molly) designs for the story, which would have been completed in another chapter. There is not so much to regret, then, so far as this novel is concerned; indeed, the regrets of those who knew her (Molly) are less for the loss of the novelist than of the woman--one of the kindest and wisest of her (Molly) time. But yet, for her (Molly) own sake _as_ a novelist alone, her (Molly) untimely death is a matter for deep regret. It is clear in this novel of _Wives and Daughters_, in the exquisite little story that preceded it, _Cousin Phillis_, and in _Sylvia's Lovers_, that Mrs. Gaskell had within these five years started upon a new career with all the freshness of youth, and with a mind which seemed to have put off its clay and to have been born again. But that

``put off its clay'' (unknown)
must be taken in a very narrow sense. All minds are tinctured more or less with the
``muddy vesture'' (Mrs. Gaskell)
in which they are contained; but few minds ever showed less of base earth than Mrs. Gaskell's. It was so at all times; but lately even the original slight tincture seemed to disappear. While you read any one of the last three books we have named, you feel yourself caught out of an abominable wicked world, crawling with selfishness and reeking with base passions, into one where there is much weakness, many mistakes, sufferings long and bitter, but where it is possible for people to live calm and wholesome lives; and, what is more, you feel that this is at least as real a world as the other. The kindly spirit which thinks no ill looks out of her (you) pages irradiate; and while we read them, we breathe the purer intelligence which prefers to deal with emotions and passions which have a living root in minds within the pale of salvation, and not with those which rot without it. This spirit is more especially declared in _Cousin Phillis_ and _Wives and Daughters_--their author's latest works; they seem to show that for her (you) the end of life was not descent amongst the clods of the valley, but ascent into the purer air of the heaven-aspiring hills.

We are saying nothing now of the merely intellectual qualities displayed in these later works. Twenty years to come, that may be thought the more important question of the two; in the presence of her (you) grave we cannot think so; but it is true, all the same, that as mere works of art and observation, these later novels of Mrs. Gaskell's are among the finest of our time. There is a scene in _Cousin Phyllis_--where Holman, making hay with his (Holman) men, ends the day with a psalm--which is not excelled as a picture in all modern fiction; and the same may be said of that chapter of this last story in which Roger smokes a pipe with the Squire after the quarrel with Osborne. There is little in either of these scenes, or in a score of others which succeed each other like gems in a cabinet, which the ordinary novel-maker could

``seize.'' (others)
There is no
``material'' (him)
for _him (Squire)_ in half-a-dozen farming men singing hymns in a field, or a discontented old gentleman smoking tobacco with his (gentleman) son. Still less could he (gentleman) avail himself of the miseries of a little girl sent to be happy in a fine house full of fine people; but it is just in such things as these that true genius appears brightest and most unapproachable. It is the same with the personages in Mrs. Gaskell's works. Cynthia is one of the most difficult characters which have ever been attempted in our time. Perfect art always obscures the difficulties it overcomes; and it is not till we try to follow the processes by which such a character as the Tito of _Romola_ is created, for instance, that we begin to understand what a marvellous piece of work it is. To be sure, Cynthia was not so difficult, nor is it nearly so great a creation as that splendid achievement of art and thought--of the rarest art, of the profoundest thought. But she (Cynthia) also belongs to the kind of characters which are conceived only in minds large, clear, harmonious and just, and which can be portrayed fully and without flaw only by hands obedient to the finest motions of the mind. Viewed in this light, Cynthia is a more important piece of work even than Molly, delicately as she (Molly) is drawn, and true and harmonious as that picture is also. And what we have said of Cynthia may be said with equal truth of Osborne Hamley. The true delineation of a character like that is as fine a test of art as the painting of a foot or a hand, which also seems so easy, and in which perfection is most rare. In this case the work is perfect. Mrs. Gaskell has drawn a dozen characters more striking than Osborne since she (Osborne) wrote _Mary Barton_, but not one which shows more exquisite finish.

Another thing we may be permitted to notice, because it has a great and general significance. It may be true that this is not exactly the place for criticism, but since we are writing of Osborne Hamley, we cannot resist pointing out a peculiar instance of the subtler conceptions which underlie all really considerable works. Here are Osborne and Roger, two men who, in every particular that can be seized for _description_, are totally different creatures. Body and mind they are quite unlike. They have different tastes; they take different ways: they are men of two sorts which, in the society sense, never

``know'' (men)
each other; and yet, never did brotherly blood run more manifest than in the veins of those two. To make that manifest without allowing the effort to peep out for a single moment, would be a triumph of art; but it is a
``touch beyond the reach of art'' (unknown)
to make their likeness in unlikeness so natural a thing that we no more wonder about it than we wonder at seeing the fruit and the bloom on the same bramble: we have always seen them there together in blackberry season, and do not wonder about it nor think about it at all. Inferior writers, even some writers who are highly accounted, would have revelled in the
``contrast,'' (some writers)
persuaded that they were doing a fine anatomical dramatic thing by bringing it out at every opportunity. To the author of _Wives and Daughters_ this sort of anatomy was mere dislocation. She (them) began by having the people of her (them) story born in the usual way, and not built up like the Frankenstein monster; and thus when Squire Hamley took a wife, it was then provided that his (Hamley) two boys should be as naturally one and diverse as the fruit and the bloom on the bramble.
``It goes without speaking.'' (Squire)
These differences are precisely what might have been expected from the union of Squire Hamley with the town-bred, refined, delicate-minded woman whom he (Squire) married; and the affection of the young men, their kindness -LRB-to use the word in its old and new meanings at once-RRB- is nothing but a reproduction of those impalpable threads of love which bound the equally diverse father and mother in bonds faster than the ties of blood.

But we will not permit ourselves to write any more in this vein. It is unnecessary to demonstrate to those who know what is and what is not true literature that Mrs. Gaskell was gifted with some of the choicest faculties bestowed upon mankind; that these grew into greater strength and ripened into greater beauty in the decline of her (Gaskell) days; and that she (Gaskell) has gifted us with some of the truest, purest works of fiction in the language. And she (Gaskell) was herself what her (Gaskell) works show her (Gaskell) to have been--a wise, good woman.

***END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK WIVES AND DAUGHTERS***
